review_title: Overall good but favoritism in promotions
pros: Mostly great colleagues, albeit a few who only cater to leadership. Excellent benefits, culture of innovation, many smart people at headquarters.
cons:
Have witnessed a lot of favoritism with promotions, in CA&O and particularly MABI. People doing more than others not promoted (more products, higher budgets, more work hours, managing more people) but those who are favorites of leadership are promoted with little basis for the promotion. Some groups are clearly favored more than others due to viability with leadership.
Advice to Management
Keep up the innovation and great hiring. Please promote those who deserve it based on merit, not who leadership favors.

Helpful (1

pros:
Top benefits for Midwest area
Encouraged to gain experience in multiple areas within
Supportive co-workers
Diverse
cons:
Be prepared to give up personal life and hobbies completely to work here. Kiss family values good bye. Expected to work 24-7, weekends or whenever is asked. No day under 12+ hours.

Plenty of PTO and development opportunities, but (finance) employees are unable to actually use or participate in.

PTO policy is use or loose within the year.

Often required to work US holidays but OUS coworkers not required to.

Zero time for value add job improvements because too much redo of work. Lots of hierarchy and red tape for everything. Leadership is NOT uniform or aligned on expectations.
Advice to Management
Make a radical change to improve hours. Expectation of 12+ hour days every day is not sustainable. 

Leadership should reduce the amount of rework, perhaps by limiting the red tape needed to get through a given process.
Helpful (1

pros: I worked at 3 other companies prior to getting a job here, and even after a year of working here I continue to be impressed. Since this is a huge company, everything will vary from team to team obviously, but I feel extremely valued here and like my personal time is respected. I feel like the managers really care about me as a person rather than just someone that can provide results, and that makes a huge difference in how I view my work overall. On top of it, the company is really good at listening to you when you voice any concerns and innovative ideas rather than shutting it down. They'll let you try for new things even if said new things lead to a dead end. This makes me really appreciate where I work.
cons:
Pay is less than it would be at other companies. Abbvie definitely makes up for this in all other areas, but the pay is hard not to notice when I talk to my friends that are in the same field at other places.
Advice to Management
Keep listening to your employees like you are and respecting them. This is how you keep having the best talent

pros: Generally, I feel good about working here, just celebrated 6 years.
cons:
It was disappointing and stressful to receive the email regarding returning to work, in the midst of a pandemic, at the start of flu season. I (along with many others), have been perfectly capable of working remotely, from the safety of my home. In fact, I probably am more productive at home since I don’t have to worry about commuting and small talk that wastes so much time. I don’t understand the justification as to why AbbVie would think that returning to a huge office, at full capacity, is a good idea. I thought it was just me, but then I saw the news article today and I’m relieved I’m not alone. Naturally, I feared that there would be repercussions for voicing my opinions. I am hoping AbbVie can also rise to this challenge, as it’s employees have, and move forward with being flexible with remote working. Reducing the office footprint could potentially save millions in rent/overhead too.
Advice to Management
The CEO should listen to the employees.

pros: The benefits for Medical, PTO and Holidays started at the start of hire. Upper management was very engaged with the wellbeing of the employees and conducting educational company town hall meetings. Very nice building.
cons:
Within the Customer Complaints Handling and FDA Reportable Events Document Control Department, the management had challenges with proper direction and control with collaborating with their partnered companies and the FDA process. New Hire Training was not sufficient and not supported to properly have an employee feel confident and comfortable with performing the duties and tasks to follow the strict guidelines in reporting pharmaceutical and product discrepancies for patients and pharmacies. Some team members were supportive, some were not as kind and friendly.
Advice to Management
Focus on identifying the exact processes and time limits required for document control between all parties involved, then design a proper plan ,(standard of operation), the will not cause unnecessary minimal time restrictions to complete a complaint report. Other departments would hold onto a report for review far too long before submitting to the Complaints Team for final FDA filing, causing undue stress.

These superficial effort is not fundamentally solving any problem as the key management positions to the critical business are largely white male. At the end of the day, you can be your own judge when you see there is no change in the top management. Spare me those useless seminars, which helped no one but some HRs.
Advice to Management
HR: Stop asking me to send you an email and provide you the feedback when my feedback is right here on Glassdoor. Have you not heard Ctrl+C?
Helpful (3)
AbbVie Response
October 5, 2020 – Talent Acquisition
Thank you for sharing your feedback with us. Not only are we are concerned about the experiences of AbbVie employees, but we’re actively concerned about the state of racial equality and social justice. We’re taking action to ensure that AbbVie leads by example in every area of our company. One example is the creation of the new Chief Equity Officer role who is responsible for leading by understanding and addressing opportunities, internally and externally, related to issues of race, equity and diversity. This will take time, but we are committed to driving positive change. We also measure progress related to Equality, Diversity and Inclusion in our Responsible Action Report

pros: Good Compensation Structure. Short and long term benefits.
cons:
-Abbvie 'culture'
-"We have employees safety first and foremost" could not be more false and hypocritical. The emphasis and importance placed on being in the office for roles that do not require, in any fashion, to be physically present is truly remarkable, disturbing, and really just sad.
-In the typical Abbvie elitist mindset, the leaders believe we are above the pandemic and can simply ignore it. It is clear now they believe not being in the office is hurting business (despite evidence to the contrary) and that forcing knowledge employees to go back to normal office culture will solve sales problems that have nothing to do with being face-to-face in a conference room and everything to do with external factors such as.... you guessed it... the PANDEMIC happening!
-VP and above self-perception of immortal omnipotent beings yet all are afraid to voice a dissenting opinion to anyone above them. This is a Yes-man/woman environment. 
-Profits over all else mentality despite an above-average attempt to mask it with patient-centric propaganda machine firing on all cylinders internally and externally. I can't stress this point enough. COVID has clearly revealed Abbvie does not care about anything besides profits with respect to employees and patients.
Advice to Management
Yahoo thought they won the search wars, MySpace thought it would never lose its monopoly, Nokia '1 billion customers - can anyone catch them?'


This will be Abbvie's fate if we keep looking backwards instead of forwards. 

Do we want to be the Google & Facebook of pharma or the forgotten Nokia? 

Unfortunately we talk an innovation game but in practice we operate like it is the 90s or earlier in some areas.

review_title: An old-school employer who tries to improve presence in the Bay Area, but still retains the Chicago mentality
pros: Very good team of scientists.
cons:
The company has a caste system. The caste is divided by grade. Managers have grade 18 and above, while minion employees have grade 17 and below. Minion employees are the life blood of the company, yet have no stock, 8% bonus with no performance modifier, and will have to jump through many layers of politics to get promoted. Meanwhile, managers will qualify for stock, 15% bonus with performance modifier ( up to 200% modifier), and exclusive access to fast-track promotion. As the company tries to consolidate three sites in the Bay Area and move to SSF, in the words of Tom Hudson, the company’s CSO, this move will bring more opportunity to everyone. Yet, what we saw in the past three years were fast track promotions to all the managers. Now there are a lot of Directors, Managers, Senior Directors, etc etc. The minion employees are left behind with no clear vision of advancement. At the same time, the managers have the privilege to work from home in their little castles for a foreseeable future, and the minion employees are all recalled on-site to work. To add salt to the injury, the company took back the free lunch benefit for onsite workers, and leave the employees struggle to find lunch. The implementation of Eat Club has been a disaster.
Advice to Management
Treat your minion employees well.
Helpful (6)
AbbVie Response
October 20, 2020 – Talent Acquisition
Thank you for sharing your feedback with us. We have a strong commitment to employee satisfaction and wish to discuss your feedback in more detail. If willing, please reach out to us at HRConnect.northamerica@abbvie.com. We look forward to hearing from you
advice_to_mgmt: Treat your minion employees well.

review_title: Does not value employee well being!
pros: Great team and company mission

You cannot force people to collaborate and meet face-to-face if they are not comfortable with it. Why does an HR or IT employee need to be on site when they can go home. They will only risk themselves, other employers and their families. It's a hypocrisy when company says they are working for COVID-19 drugs. 
If you do not value employees, you do not value the health or well-being of customers. 
This short term focus on bottom line at expense of employee and society well-being will come to bite the company! The company didn't learn from what happened at Biogen with COVID-19. Look elsewhere, most of the other employers including in pharma & healthcare are much more flexible!

review_title: Overall good company with some challenges
pros:
There are a few brand teams with great culture, which is fostered at the top with leaders who possess a growth mindset. 
Encourages volunteering, established Employer Resource Groups, dedicated to company match on donations.
It's part of the accepted culture for folks to sit down and connect for a 1:1 over lunch or a coffee break. Always received a warm reception to an invitation to meet.
cons:
The decision making is known to be hierarchal; most projects have to go up the flag pole to be green lit.
Timely communication is a challenging for hierarchal teams. This has a tendency to leave new hires and lower grade employees out of the loop on important directional changes. 
When joining a team, a colleague or ally is needed to explain the team dynamics and culture, otherwise missteps at the beginning can tarnish one's reputation.

pros: Good benefits, they have retirement
cons:
Closed knit culture, you will be unable to pierce the community walls, that would be off limits for an outsider.
Outsider could be anyone: a person of color, not the right gender, have a thought outside of the box, management doesn't like them, etc
A bit toxic where they will be nice to you on face but won't give career opportunities to grow or advance. Many marketing directors don't have the right background or experience and have done only one or two things in marketing. Or have been with the brand for long enough in sales and are made marketing directors. Some of these Marketing Directors don't know to even read a financial report or simple KPIs, but they get backing from Sr Leadership as they fit their club (white). It's unfortunate but hey that's what they want as a company. 
If you look at AbbVie's leadership team, there is mostly white men and one or two women. Isn't that something, when non white men and women have not pierced at that level then it also shows why? because no organic encouragement within the company.
Advice to Management
Assess talent well and let them be managed by better talent. Don't hire talent and tell them what to do, hire talent so they tell you what to do. Include some diversity including your leadership and board will help with company image, at least.

review_title: Good benefits, not great at incorporating talent
pros: Good compensation, great benefits, global company.
cons:
Beware the “lifer” mentality. Some who have had entire careers with Abbott are parochial and old school in their views and really see no reason to grow professionally themselves. It can be a shock to someone coming from the outside to learn that their experience is not understood and talents aren’t incorporated or recognized. So some managers will pretend you have no valuable experience at all. If all your experience did not happen at Abbott or you are not fresh from postdoc, it didn’t happen. I know a lot of mid-career people who come to Abbvie from other jobs to find themselves underemployed and stuck.
Advice to Management
You can learn a lot from people coming into the company.. The lifer mentality can be cyclical so think about who is training/influencing your upcoming generations of talent. Keep up with the times! And do something about toxic managers.

review_title: Strong Technical Vision - Finally cleaning house
pros:
Amazing company and team with a strong culture changes in Infrastructure from the new leadership with a strong technical vision (from Associate Director and Up) - with a bias to action. The VP's and Sr. D's all want to see the teams thrive and we are seeing recognition for our work. 

We are finally getting rid of some of the dead weight - and driving new culture and architectures like SD-WAN, CNF and Data. 

A number of promotions in EA & Engineering of strong technologists who put the patient at the center of what we do - and this past year the new management is finally cleaning out the deadweight who have held us back for years. 

We are building a whole new platform with some amazing new technologies and the chief technologists 3 year strategy will drive more automation and giving us time to work with the new tech (instead of relying on consultants). 

Amazing emerging technology pipeline that will revolutionize IT @ AbbVie.
cons:
Some of the group is having a hard time with 2019 change (mainly those that should be worried) but I admit I was nervous too. That said the new 2019 leadership team in the combined ea/tech/infra group is helping drive through change and being empathic / respectful to everyone's needs giving everyone a chance. The fact is some people aren't making the "cut" and some house cleaning is happening. People are worried about RIF's with Allergan and the implementation of Automation, but there is so much work ahead that we need to trust leadership has our backs.
Advice to Management
Don't shy away from challenging the status quo, you are making a difference driving benefits to our patients - in times of change people fear the worst and hope for the best - look past it and drive with your strong technical leadership team who cares about the people. Don't let us fall back into the old ways.

BTW Make sure we continue to have the employee engineers / architects do the new stuff learning from the consultants.

Most of us couldn't be prouder to be part of BTS and Infra/TechDev.
Helpfu

review_title: Your experience is dependent on the department you work
pros: Benefits are quite impressive, including pension. The building is evolving and modernizing. There are several long-term employees who started at Abbott who stayed on when Abbvie became independent. The level of science is high, resulting in getting much needed products to patients. Very diverse work force and many opportunities for all. Salaries align with fair market value in the state.
cons:
It depends on what group you are in to determine the workload that is expected of you. Other reviews claim a good work/life balance while my experience and that of colleagues proves otherwise. Working at home after hours and weekends is necessary to meet deadlines. I heard of at least one employee who routinely stays until 1:00 AM to complete their work while another co-worker claimed they are working much harder than they did in a academic job, which are notoriously demanding. Scientists conduct experiments but don't have time to document them in the electronic notebook. The salary is good but you will work for it at the expense of personal time.
Advice to Management
Management is not monolithic. Before accepting a job at Abbvie, do your research on the group where you will be working.

review_title: Tolerance of bad leadership makes environment toxic
pros: One of the best compensation packages in industry, including pension. Some people are great to work with and very team-oriented.
cons:
(1) Poor leadership is tolerated, which creates a toxic environment for that group. These leaders continue to be advanced and their high rates of turnover are ignored. AbbVie is bleeding talent because of poor leadership. Employee Relations is useless and only protects the leader. (2) Promotion is highly political and based on who you know rather than who does the best job or has the best skills. (3) Some managers will block their employees from transferring to different positions. (4) Although they say they encourage behaviors (Ways of Working) and values, the behavior that is reinforced by leadership contradicts this. (5) Decisions for some scientific functions borders unethical/non-compliant yet everyone looks the other way. People who do speak up are reprimanded or it's held against them.
Advice to Management
Get rid of bad leaders. AbbVie could be a great company if you did.
Helpful (5)
AbbVie Response
September 10, 2019 – Social Media Specialist
We appreciate your feedback. We are committed to equal employment opportunities for all and employment decisions are based on business needs, job requirements, and individual qualifications. At AbbVie, conducting business ethically and in compliance with the law is one of our highest priorities. We would like to hear more about your concerns. Please feel free to reach out to us at oec@abbvie.com or HRCentral.UnitedStates@abbvie.com. Concerns may be reported anonymously
advice_to_mgmt: Get rid of bad leaders. AbbVie could be a great company if you did.

review_title: Outsourcing is getting out of control at Abbvie. Quality going down the tubes.
pros: Good compensation, good work-life balance
cons:
push to outsource anyone they can, which has contributed to a huge decrease in quality of Safety and Product Quality reports. Outsourcing to Philippines, India, Budapest. Abbvie claims to be patient centric, but by outsourcing those who actually engage with patients, patients have a much more frustrating experience when reporting an issue. 
Also, the departments tend to bring in management from other departments that have no knowledge of the actual systems or processes that the employees use. This makes for the employees constantly having to educate management on what is going on. Why does Abbvie not move those with the most knowledge into management? I have seen it happen time and time again, and I have worked in 3 different departments. It leads to strong employees getting frustrated that they are passed over for a promotion for someone with less knowledge. Just because someone has been a manager in one area, doesn't mean you can throw them in to another department, and they will automatically be a good fit. I have seen managers make so many mistakes and almost ruin departments due to a lack of knowledge and an unwillingness to gain the knowledge needed to perform their job.
Advice to Management
Promote your best people, stop bringing in outside managers simply because you used to work with them in another department. Stop outsourcing everything! I understand the need to make profits, but what happens in audit situations when the quality has gone down the toilet? It takes so many more hours of work by employees to fix the messes created by all of the vendors you have outsourced the work to. Is this really saving money???? And by the way, I'm not against outsourcing because I just want to keep my job at all costs. I am against it because I have seen first hand the cluster my department has become.

pros:
Basic Information: 
This position of Study Management Associate ("SMA") is the same job I had at one of my previous companies, except they called this same job "Clinical Trial Associate". And one of my friends has this same general type of job, and their company calls this job Operations Associate. Compared to some of my past jobs, the AbbVie SMA position seems like a blend between an in-house non-data-monitoring clinical research associate, systems administrator, and document control eTMF employee. 

This is not a clinical study manager, project manager, line manager, team leader, monitoring, data, patient safety, science, or medical affairs clinical research position. SMA2s and SMA3s report equally to a Project Manager. The Project Managers make all decisions, and the SMAs carry out the decisions. Every once in a while, another SMA co-worker wishes this job was project manager, so they just go ahead and pretend like they are, and get kind of pushy to their equal co-workers or try to one-up team members. This doesn't happen all the time or on every team, and the situation is manageable, but it does pop up just occasionally. This probably happens at other companies too though.

For job duties, the clinical research study sites are divided between the SMA2 and SMA3 team members, and it is part of your job to always be current with status updates about your assigned sites. But SMAs do not communicate directly with sites, so they obtain some of their site & patient updates from the clinical research monitors, vendor reports, and from study information which comes from other AbbVie departments. And SMAs send communication and requests to the sites through the clinical research monitors. Each SMA is usually assigned to work with about 1 or 2 of the study vendors (like the companies who handle pathology screening or x-rays of study patients, etc). And the other operational study duties are divided between the team members. The project managers are very nice about setting aside regular time to get to know you and check how things are going, and discuss with you if there is any special project you might like to work on, based on your interests, then they help you find learning activities for your development to support this. And speaking of management, I never saw any bad politics with upper management.
cons:
Basic Information continued:
At AbbVie company, the clinical trial duties are very separated and silo'd between departments. The other departments produce the study design and study documents, and it is our job to communicate with them to get information and documents. And vice versa, we also run reports and give information to other departments when they request it from us. I don't feel as burned out here compared to other places, since the other departments do the harder parts of the study, and we can concentrate better on our job which is study communications and tracking. Project managers do some of those same things at a higher level, and also more quality assurance work, and line management/ performance reviews. There are many systems already in place for everything, so everything is very nice & orderly. A large part of this job is also working with the software systems that keep track of the study information and the study documents. (It is not difficult. Someone can show you how to do it in 10 minutes.) SMAs also have a lot of teleconference calls with monitors, team members, and vendors. A large portion of the job is updating trackers, spreadsheets, and meeting minutes. Periodically if an SMA or project manager wants to make up a new project for them self, they make up more complicated spreadsheets to keep tracking things.

The pay is nice, and we get a yearly bonus. The office atmosphere is very nice and modern, and they are flexible about working remote.

Too many!! internal promotions is impossible. They praises you until the annual review and then give you average or below average reviews so you stay at your current position. Employees back stabbed you. You can’t trust on your own team. Training is poor if you ask for help they hold it against you. Too much work load. Compensation is similar like any other pharmaceutical. Very long hiring time. Your manager never takes your side instead play a role of devils advocate. Your tons of good work goes unnoticed and any tiny mistake gets highlighted and frowned upon. Hiring process is a joke. It can takes months. Your manager initially plays friends and extract your career expectations then basically block your growth. Horrible experience my manager even block my exit interview. My manager was the reason I left such a great company and a noble cause.
Advice to Management
Don’t hire manager with basic degrees and let them manage a team of people with advance degree. Conduct anonymous employee survey to know the truth about upper management.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Don’t hire manager with basic degrees and let them manage a team of people with advance degree. Conduct anonymous employee survey to know the truth about upper management.

pros:
- People, people, people. I made life-long friends working at AbbVie.
- Culture is amazing. People genuinely want to help and look out for each other.
- There are some variations, but in general, senior leaders are very strong. The strategy they set make perfect sense.
- Flexible work schedule. There are many working parents so you are almost expected to put your family first.
- While the company's benefits are quite similar to other companies, some of the perks are amazing (some company holidays, maternal/paternal leaves which span up to 6 months).
cons:
- Decisions can be made VERY slowly. Too many layers of decisions makers.
- I've seen some office politics get in the way.
- Your career path is almost set - you may need to check some boxes in order to be promoted.
- That said, some people are promoted way too quickly that makes you scratch your head. 
- Job title is depreciated.
Helpfu

pros: generous compensation considering lower cost of living in the greater Chicago area, great work life balance,

May 20, 2019 – Talent Acquisition

If you would like to share more details regarding your concerns you can contact HR Central at 844-663-4748 or HRCentral.UnitedStates@abbvie.com

pros:
- Culture and work/life balance on the whole in Lake County R&D seems much better than most of my friends' experiences at other large pharma/biotech at the coasts (and also anecdotally, the CA and MA AbbVie sites) 

- There's currently a good mix of recent hires/young scientists and "lifers" - people who have been working at the bench at Abbott/AbbVie for decades and have a ton of institutional knowledge and hands-on experience.

- Benefits and compensation for PhD level positions in Lake County are good, especially considering lower cost-of-living than the coastal sites
cons:
- Raises aren't much better than cost of living. On the coasts, PhD-level scientists seem to hop between companies to get large bumps in pay or position - since we're the only large company, that's not an option unless you want to move.

- There's some occasional corporate nonsense, but no more than I would expect from any company (or even universities if you get a faculty position)

- The evaluation process and how it leads or doesn't lead to promotions is really opaque.
Advice to Management
- Would appreciate more clarity on how evaluations and promotions work - the only information out there is mainly gossip, and an opaque process can breed concerns of bias

- Some of the employee programs are completely pointless. Reducing people's health care plan premium if they attend a certain number of online classes wastes time we would spend working and there's no evidence it improves heath and reduces health care costs
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt:
- Would appreciate more clarity on how evaluations and promotions work - the only information out there is mainly gossip, and an opaque process can breed concerns of bias

pros: The compensation package is excellent and I am surrounded by very smart people. I take pride in working for a company that strives to solve some of the biggest health challenges people face and believe in AbbVie's intentions to put patients first.
cons:
I and many of my peers have become very cynical in the last 8 months about the culture of this company. HR has become way too powerful, and the intention to create our culture has backfired to the point it is corrosive. I am definitely not alone in feeling this way - there is a lot of cynicism. We all know that companies have no loyalty to employees, that is just business, yet in the old Abbott culture there was at least more respect. I feel that AbbVie is headed towards the "GE" culture of the bottom 10% are out. If that is the intention, HR should stop being so hypocritical and just state as such instead of expecting everyone to drink the Kool Aid that AbbVie cares about its employees' development. The truth is that AbbVie only cares about approximately 5% of its employees' development. Strong employees are made to feel useless simply because their managers have chosen to champion/support someone else, and we are all only as valuable as our last performance rating. The performance calibration process is disgusting to the point of almost being childish.
Advice to Management
Do not let HR run rampant and use some common sense. Recognize that our performance review system is severely flawed in that it is very inconsistent throughout the company with some functions (i.e. Finance) having a much more stringent "bar" than others. Recognize that there is a certain degree to which it is arbitrary who ends up on the "key talent" list. You cannot run the company with only a small percentage of the employee population, yet those who do not have a guardian angel advocating for them are basically told every day they are worthless.
Helpful (15)

pros: work/life balance, innovative therapies to millions of patients globally, smart colleagues, internal mobility is encouraged, profit-sharing, high margin business, free shuttles, subsidized healthy food options, decent vacation/paid time off, top global pharma company with strong financial results/fundamentals and strong therapies/pipeline of medicines in areas of unmet need
cons:
Large corporate politics, difficult to move up if not part of a formal "career development program" or very well connected with senior leadership (through mentoring), some nepotism exists particularly in career development programs, given organization's size, work can be highly specialized and siloed depending on group/department, only 1 formal performance review per year, very far from downtown Chicago, flexibility to work from home varies by department/group and manager, some of Abbott's legacy culture still remains (if it's not broken don't fix it mentality), innovation isn't encouraged or rewarded equally in all departments, some main buildings lack a gym facility,
Advice to Management
Improve performance evaluation transparency by adding at least one formal written mid-year review so that employees can improve where needed and enhance their career growth while adding value to the company/increasing efficiency. Accelerate career growth of high performers despite not being in a formal development program or being mentored by senior leadership to progress (i.e. reward performance not connections). Improve diversity in recruiting (i.e. minorities, diversify target schools, not just the same schools that leadership or their children attended). Encourage/incentivize innovation in all areas to improve as a whole. Incentivize innovation and team-work, not just on paper, but by rewarding employees who demonstrate these attributes through results. Do not promote to management those who are strong individual contributors, but lack or have not demonstrated leadership skills. Some managers lack people/management skills, emotional intelligence, empathy, and desire/interest to develop others or work collaboratively. Live out the "All for One AbbVie" motto and don't promote those who are clearly only looking out for their own benefit at the expense of the team. Reward efficiency and improvement, not just face-time and "hard work" that is inefficient.
Helpful (2

review_title: Run, Don't Walk Away from AbbVie
pros: If you get the right manager, compensation and benefits are good.
cons:
Bullying and backstabbing behaviors permitted and practiced all the way up to the top, particularly in corporate functions. I witnessed behavior at AbbVie by senior management that would not be permitted at other companies. Also, the culture is Abbott-centric and often incompetent people are placed in positions of great responsibility without any qualifications other than they worked at Abbott and tell management what they want to hear. There is a general aversion to risk and managers are reluctant to act on ideas that come from new employees who didn't work at Abbott. Also, there is NO capacity to push back on bad ideas coming from management. Delivering bad news is another no-no. The backstabbing was really the last straw and reason why I left for another role at a different company. Normal companies wouldn't permit such obvious sabotage but, at AbbVie, it is seemingly encouraged by some managers. Apparently, they learned this behavior from Abbott according to people with Abbott experience.
Advice to Management
8/10 members of the senior leadership come from Abbott. Ask most of them to retire immediately (they can afford it) and start over. Also, start to take employee complaints about managers' behavior seriously.

review_title: Condescending Management and Double Standards for Code of Conduct
pros: Great benefits but low salary
cons:
Not one or two but four of my managers and senior managers held grudge, and were condescending, disparaging and threatening subordinates all the time. Managers simply didn't care about people's personal or emotional needs even in extreme cases of death of loved ones (e.g. spouse, parent) let alone everyday challenges that necessitate flexible work schedule. Work-life balance is a cruel joke and remote work is an alien concept altogether, strongly discouraged and requests are mostly denied as top leaders simply don't trust their employees and want to see bodies in office instead. Who gets the office cubicles closer to windows depends on their perceived performance. Those doing menial tasks can just forget about being able to look outside the window once in a while from their chairs. There's no respect, no dignity once your manager dislikes you because you disagreed with them. It's the manager's way or the highway. There's no healthy debate because managers behave like they know everything about everything. There's no meaningful training that addresses one's true learning needs. If you don't know something already, you're automatically treated like you're incapable of learning.

Equally disturbing is how and how often managers' and senior leaders' offensive behavior is not just condoned but not even acknowledged. Human Resources employees conspicuously lack the "human" touch and feel and always side with the managers. So registering a formal complaint against mistreatment or rude behavior is guaranteed to backfire and met with elaborate retaliation schemes despite labor laws.

Despite constant verbal claims and comparisons to cultures at former parent Abbott Labs or erstwhile Hospira (now owned by Pfizer), leaders are more focused on petty politics and constantly engaged in infighting or punishing or finding faults in employees than building a differentiating work culture that values basic trust, human dignity, collaboration, innovation, appreciation and recognition - even simple verbal acknowledgment - for employees' hard work and contributions, and above all one common code of conduct for everyone regardless of their hierarchical position.
Helpful (7)
AbbVie Response
August 6, 2018 – Talent Acquisition
AbbVie is committed to providing employees with a work environment free of harassment. We believe in respecting the dignity of every individual. At AbbVie, we strive for a culture that is inclusive and transparent, and provides a work life balance. Please reach out to the Ethics and Compliance Helpline with your concerns at 1-800-254-0462 or oec@abbvie.com. You may also reach out directly to Employee Relations. Concerns can be reported anonymously

Helpful (3)
AbbVie Response
January 23, 2018 – Talent Acquisition
Thank you for your feedback. The process you are referring to, called Skip Level Meetings, is a common business practice. Leaders conduct these meetings is to gain additional insight to what's happening in the company, and the goal is to provide a positive experience and give more junior employees access to more senior leaders. Skip levels aren’t mandatory at AbbVie, but they are consistent with AbbVie’s Talent Philosophy. We have 5 principles for leading people, and a critical one is transparency, thus we encourage leaders and employees to have these transparent conversations. That mean Leaders have to be skilled. To drive that, we introduced specific measures of people leadership, Our People Leader Attributes, in January 2017. Our training and development has been revised, to drive world class people leader behaviors. Mostly we get it very right. Our employee engagement is at world class levels. But we cannot, and will not, take the importance of leadership for granted, and so we thank you for your feedback
advice_to_mgmt: Act like researchers and be curious about what is happening in your department. Clean house in U.S. and Global at the director level.

review_title: If they can't treat their employees well how do you think they care about patients?
pros: The money was good. The benefits was good. Especially the profit sharing. Big money! Lots of money to throw around which is nice if employed there.
cons:
They may preach about how well they treat patients on Humira and Lupron (not entirely true) but they are awful to employees, even long time employees who fall ill, even with same indications as their patients. I have been in and out of specialist offices, having surgeries and returning to work never been treated so poorly. I've been harrassed for taking to long in the washroom, using washroom too much, and I've had notes from Dr's asking to please excuse due to nature of surgery. The notes went ignored. Having over lapping illnesses endometriosis, polycystic ovarian disease, degenerative disc disease and Hidrenitis Supperveda puts enough stress on a body. But coming back to work from medical leave to be put on a performance plan because my call score fluctuated in the 90's was harsh. Fired two days after my 16 year anniversary.
Advice to Management
It's not fair to put a one sided story on one's review without getting both sides. Especially if you weren't there. Also many people in the Pharmacy suffered false statements on reviews because of inaccurate reporting tools. The voicemails for Psp for starters. There are also people who received "Excellent" reviews because of favortism. These people don't do any more work than anyone else. The fact is they know something they are needed to be kept quiet about. Someone needs to do some serious investigations in that pharmacy. Especially some audits! Start drug testing as well.

pros: Great company overall for learning the industry. Great pay and benefits. Steer towards Supply Chain, manufacturing or support areas but stay clear of the pharmacy, at least from my perspective, unless you like running in circles.
cons:
Poor management selection, you have to be a yes man and too many managers with a lack of experience running loose making decisions which can be detrimental to the company when discovered in audits. No real future for the pharmacy if they can't get more products and reduce costs. Changes being made prior to procedures being updated. Sups and managers blatantly telling you to just do it anyway even if a process is wrong.
Advice to Management
Seriously review the ethical and quality issues that really occur. Turn it inside out. You will find violations in every corner if you look hard enough. I know where those are. As for saving your investment, you are way too top heavy with management and there is too much waste trying to appease employees who are already paid well to do a job. Get rid of the favoritism and games played by those on power struggles such as leads and sups. Create a standardized process for all leaders to follow and not allow for employees to be terminated based on personal issues management is having on any given day.
Helpful (8
advice_to_mgmt: Seriously review the ethical and quality issues that really occur. Turn it inside out. You will find violations in every corner if you look hard enough. I know where those are. As for saving your investment, you are way too top heavy with management and there is too much waste trying to appease employees who are already paid well to do a job. Get rid of the favoritism and games played by those on power struggles such as leads and sups. Create a standardized process for all leaders to follow and not allow for employees to be terminated based on personal issues management is having on any given day.

pros: Abbvie's genuine commitment to open exchange of ideas and sharing of information in order to advance new drug technology makes it both a challenge and privilege for IT GRC. At Abbvie both commitments are consistently kept at the forefront of business objectives FOR REAL. True respect is given to both sides of these business objectives.
cons:

review_title: Good for employees, but for contractors...
pros: The IT dept. staff are very knowledgeable and helpful. Lots of IT projects/services rolled out to simplify for end users getting help. Depending on which building you're assigned, you will be either busy or workload can be slow.
cons:
Bulky laptops still in use and laptop upgrade policy (one year past the warranty) can be an issue for people with constant hardware issues. Mandatory one month furlough for IT contractors after completing a two year contract. One month going unpaid is not for everyone and can be stressful if not planned ahead. Job advancement or becoming a permanent employee is close to zero. Contractors are sometimes left out of meetings/outings due to employees-only policy.
Advice to Management
Get rid of the mandatory furlough and convert contractors to employees or not renew. This policy is in a gray area in terms of labor laws.

cons:
Vacation, if you come with experience from other pharma/biopharm companies you are most likely going to take a step backward in time off. Most departments are ran so lean that worklife balance can be a struggle. They offer a lot of flexibility but it is your luck of draw as to if your manager supports it. Unfortunately a lot of managers are still living in the 1990s and don't support it. Lastly they talk a good talk on culture but that too is manager based, some are really living the defined and others wouldn't know what good like if it was right in front of them. This is true at the highest levels and maybe even more so.

If you want to be biopharm in culture you have to be willing to allow risk and stop being so conservative.

pros: Still have opportunity to maintain good work life balance depending on were you work. Pension program and generous vacation allowance a plus.
cons:
A lot of the old negative Abbott culture remains, so areas are not managed well and understaffed groups end up taking on others responsibilities and end up neglecting their own. Advancement from within is virtually non-existent as people are hired from outside. Expectations are not establish or defined. Therefore accountability is not maintained allowing groups to continue working with a mindset that doesn't align with the corporate vision. The vision set by the CEO is not translating down to the plants. Management mistakes are clearly visible but action to reprimand or remove those from positions happens after damage is already done. Management cliques have resurfaced so fresh ideas that do not align with the group are not considered. If you do not get on the good side of management it may be even more difficult to advance.
Advice to Management
You have many people that with many years of service that have lived through the ups and downs during the late 90s and early 2000s. Listen to those that are dedicated and stop regurgitating ideas and concepts for Abbott past that do not work. Stop promoting under qualified managers that only seek to advance their careers or using PDPs to manage groups that historically require a manager with many years of hands on experience.. Upper level directors need to establish a relationship with the people in the trenches performing the day to day work. Middle management for the most part is not being honest with the issues and have reverted back to managing goals instead of identifying major problems and implementing true remedies. Management mistakes are clearly visible but action to reprimand or remove those from positions happens after damage is already done. Lastly do not be afraid to talk to the employees. Empower employees at all levels so they continue to stay engaged about the future of this company.

pros: Great benefits, and work life balance. Generous PTO to start off with, 3 weeks plus 3 additional days off, but 10 years before you get an extra weeks vacation.
cons:
Not every dept. is managed equally. Some departments are very flexible with allowing employees work life balance and others are not. Little to no career advancement opportunities, even employees with experience and not give opportunities to interview for positions. They would rather hire outside talent than grow their internal talent. Lack of decent merit increases, most of the increase goes to top management, rather than employees that are producing results. Lots of biased favoritism in the review and merit increase process, employees are stake ranked against each other. HR seems to do nothing about this. Also asked to take on more responsibility, had a title change, with increased responsibility with no increase in salary. Worked with manager for a market adjustment, and it was not made a priority, when I followed up with the managing director, my questions were rudely dismissed. Not all areas of the company are like this, but it was my experience.
Advice to Management
Advocate to hire internal candidates over external if they are qualified. Improve the review process so employees are treated equally, without bias. Be better coaches, your salaries are significantly high, with little actual people management skills to foster growth and development.

★★★★★
 Recommends
Positive Outlook

I have been working at AbbVie
Pros
-Career advancement opportunities
-Pension
-401(k) match
-About $120 a month for single person for health insurance/vision/medical
-Management putting emphasis on employee development/training
-Country bonuses a lot higher then US bonuses (twice as high). If you work overseas, bonuses for managers can be upto 18% and stock options offered. This isn't offered to US employees.
-Strong pipeline but could take some years
-Depending on the manager pretty ok with work/life balance
-Town halls where employees can voice their concerns to Sr Management
-Vacation time pretty reasonable
Cons
-With Humira patent expiring, some job cuts and expense cut pressures. HCV pressures also not helping company and outlook a little confusing.
-Bonuses for people that are non director are mediocre (7% per year). Unless you are a director can you earn good benefits
-No yearly shutdowns
-Performance reviews can be very biased
-Hard to advance unless you know the right person. Sometimes all the skills you have may no be important but who you know
Advice to Management
-Continue to development talent
-Give employees opportunities to move. Don't just hire someone because they know someone else
-Re-look at bonus structure for employees 19 and below grade levels
-Re-align salaries so they are fair

review_title: Exciting scientific developments; culture needs to catch up
pros:
Cutting-edge science
Very good product acquisitions strategy
Nice compensation and benefits package
cons:
Too much hierarchy and too many managerial levels
Old Abbott culture still prevalent and seems antiquated
New, outside ideas from people hired from more agile organizations are not welcome: seems you have to pay many years of dues before your ideas can be heard and appreciated--by the time the dues are paid, there has been a lost opportunity. People with the fresh ideas leave or are no longer inspired to share ideas and insights. It's like "if it didn't happen at Abbott, it's not worth knowing."
Advice to Management
"New blood" who come from more agile, technologically forward companies experience culture-shock here--it's very difficult to get used to such a hierarchical organization where innovation isn't necessarily rewarded and is often discouraged. Empower people to make decisions at lower levels. Not every idea requires the same level of oversight and scrutiny. Don't tie the hands of of intelligent people for nonsensical reasons.
There is a great set of cultural initiatives in place: agility, transparency, decision-making, innovation. Until managers understand what this looks like and really embrace it, it just comes across as lip service. Walk the talk in every part of the organization, not just in scientific discovery.

advice_to_mgmt:

employee_status: IT Project Manager in Waukegan, IL
pros: Excellent pay, benefits, and perks. Gorgeous new building on 94 and 60 (Mettawa, IL) that brings in a lot of sunlight and fresh air and encourages a new mindset of creating good relationships and working well rather than being workaholics trying to preserve one's own position.
cons:
Worked in IT. Terrible bureaucracy (throwing people under the bus to protect oneself) and "this is the way we've always done it" mentality from people who have been there for 30 years (spun off from Abbott in 2013). The old attitude is making you lose young talent. review_title: Mangement Play's Favorites over better qualified
pros: Good people to work with. Good benefits.
cons:
Management not confident. A lot of them are too young to be in these positions. Most of the new managers have no experience in these positions. Management unwilling to take advice from staff. The culture they are looking for is putting stress on all employees, making it a very stressful environment. Managers play favoritism, management and HR go around the hiring system and appoint people to positions. There is no room for advancement unless your part of the "club". Very poor communications from the lower managers to the work groups. This also contributes to the management "all about me attitude" that has taken over. Managers don't care about there reports, only that you make your manager shine. Also it's all about the KPI's now. They must be "green" or you may be to blame for making them "red" Lower managers have been known to lie about them to cover their backs.

review_title: Walking on ostrich eggshells with stiletto heels
pros: Big company, nice perks (e.g., awesome foodservice offerings, Starbucks kiosks, occasional team lunches off-site, potential to make lateral or vertical moves).
cons:
Recognized the dysfunctional and emotionally and intellectual oppressiveness almost from Day One. To have to negotiate the icebergs around every other cubicle while steering a supertanker not exactly the pleasantest experience. Dyed in the wool toxic managers control the shipping lanes, so an overly "insightful" subordinate gets his or her occupational keel kicked in soon enough. Lemmings afraid of losing the paycheck kowtow till retirement, unless their lips lose their pucker power first.
Advice to Management
Lead by managing your managers. Hold inept supervisors and team leads accountable for more than smoke and mirror performance reviews.
Helpful (11
advice_to_mgmt: Lead by managing your managers. Hold inept supervisors and team leads accountable for more than smoke and mirror performance reviews.

review_title: Extremely Toxic Culture and Heavy-handed Managers
pros: Deceptively good benefits that come at a great cost (check your self-respect at the door before walking to your desk).
cons:
Very disrespectful treatment, pervasive verbal abuse in private so you don't have any witnesses to back you up, the HR dept. ALWAYS supports managers and NEVER the employee so the confidential Aware-line where employees can report issues is a big joke. Schedule is very rigid even in areas/functions where rigidity is not needed, so there's complete disregard for an employee's occasional need for flextime. Flextime requests even count against the employee during performance reviews! There's hardly any cooperation across various departments and most departments hold back information from each other that would otherwise make it easier to make and execute key business decisions. The validity of verbal or even written (email) agreements between project team members is questioned repeatedly which causes further delays in execution. But most of all, it's the management's inhumane treatment of employees in exchange for a few breadcrumbs that only the least competent employees with little or no self-respect will accept.
Advice to Management
Good luck after Humira loses the patent protections! The bad karma will catch up with the managers sooner or later.
Helpful (13)

Transparency and open communication are important to the culture of AbbVie and it doesn’t sound like that was your experience. We’re continuing to evolve and to work towards a culture we’d pride ourselves in as an organization. We appreciate your review and your frank message

review_title: Good old boys' club in Worcester MA
pros:
*Opportunities to learn new things and have bigger projects as people who leave are not replaced
*Decent benefits, though worse than in Abbott times
cons:
*Next to impossible to get a promotion to management if you are a minority in Worcester, MA
*Very clique-like atmosphere in Worcester, MA dominated by a couple of rival groups, who work to undermine each other.
*People you work with are frustrated, day-dreaming about quitting, toxic
*Not a meritocracy
*You have to be a white middle-age man with kids at home to be a manager, seems to be the only constant in most promotions at Abbvie in Worcester, MA
*No sense of direction from CEO
Advice to Management
I have been a long time employee in Worcester MA before I called it quits. I gave up pension, many weeks of vacation, seniority because the place has become extremely toxic at all levels. Basically, if you are not a white middle-aged man with a non-working wife and 2-3 small kids, you have no chances of ever being promoted to a more consequential role (to be read grade 18). This creates a lot of frustration, back stabbing and cliques as people try to get a "leg up" the competition. Abbvie in Worcester MA is not a meritocracy, which is ironic for an innovative company.

pros: This place is great for Manager roles and above. It is a very competitive environment and provided you have thick skin, willing to work long hours, and be a yes and... Type of person you will be successful. Just make sure to network and always smile. There is a Buzz about positive spin and post socially on everything that's positive going on right now.
cons:
Work life balance is switching to more of a work life integration mix. The company wants passionate people which will drive the company forward. When interviewing question your future boss and look for signs of how your working relationships would be. The push for lean, green and virtual are being driven in areas of where it will save money. Be prepared to work and the benefits are worth it. Just don't get stuck with a bad or new boss it could make your life at the company horrible and not provide the experience you working looking for.
Advice to Management
Senior leadership should not loose sight of all levels of the organization. During speeches examples are given that really only apply if you are in management. It makes you wonder why individual contributors are requested to attend. 

Middle management should make sure things are done the right way. So much focus is put on outputs given targets pulled out of thin air or verbal commitments and it drives individuals to have their vacations cancelled or priorities changed for tasks that are not value added for our patients or shareholders.

Overall stop ordering all this food for lunch meetings. Such a waste of money. People can bring in their own lunch and try to schedule meeting during regular hours and allow for time for people to get work done.

pros: I've been here about 4 years and started when the split from Abbott was announced. It's a good company to work for overall - nice people, great benefits, and a decent culture. I took three months maternity leave (I believe it is 8 weeks paid now) and for working mothers, it's fairly good. There is also a great day care on site. The work is always interesting and changing and there is a push towards more communication and transparency.
cons:
Long hours. Work life balance sometimes not great. Projects often not thought out well by management and require a lot of work at the lower levels are pushed through nonetheless. A lot of initiatives to make the company more "lean" means that there is constant push back when no one wants the work.
Advice to Management
Work life balance needs to improve. Less meetings. Be transparent with your employees and recognize their achievements.

The head of statistics, SAS programming and DBA management is mainland blanked out. 90% of the statisticians and SAS programmers are mainland blanked out. If you go to any number of H1B websites you will find that the group is hiring H1B at an out of control rate. There are few US citizens, and banked out, and a couple of other nationalities. There is active discrimination against any nationality other than Mainland blanked out. The main language spoken in the group is not blanked out. Sooner or later the management will be held accountable for this active discrimination policy against US citizens. Senator blanked out is now investigating. Also note, Pharmacyclics which was bought out by Abbvie is hiring statisticians and SAS programmers a lot They are keeping the group separate.
Advice to Management
Quit.
Helpful (3
advice_to_mgmt: Quit.

pros:
Medical, Dental, Vision Benefits
Company Car (watch out for their high car charges)
Profit Sharing every year
401k
Vacation 
Paid time off
cons:
AbbVie is HORRIBLE & CUT THROAT!
Gave 2 week notice and they cut me off that day from everything! Benefits ended that day at midnight and pay stopped that day as well! Do not give them 2 week notice when you leave! Make sure you leave the day before your new job starts...especially if you have a family!
DMs manage out of fear
Many Many reps are not happy at this place.
Nearly everyone looking for different opportunities.
Product pipeline is lacking.
DMs and RMs create toxic environment with reps.
Advice to Management
Get rid of the CHALLENGER selling model! HCPs perceive no value from this and only get frustrated with the constant insights BS! Managers are clueless! You need to survey your sales reps on their district managers! The one I worked for is far from a leader! Not one rep on our team respected him and he does not know how to handle his business. The environment he has created is toxic. Forgot to mention, all of the hcp's are tired of seeing him, do not like him, feel uncomfortable with him in their office, and provides absolutely ZERO value! 

Treat your employees right and DO the right thing! I gave 2 week notice (thinking I was doing right and being professional) and the company immediately cut me off! My benefits ended the day I gave notice along with my pay! Congrats to AbbVie for getting the "Heartless in Healthcare" award! $3,000 is nothing to AbbVie but to someone with a family and mouths to feed it's definitely a hard pill to swallow...especially, when you've been with the company over 10 years and then just get treated like a piece of trash! Upper management is always saying "Our people come first"...well, put your money where your mouth is. It's hard to believe a company that makes its money improving people's health is absolutely heartless and cut throat when it comes to their own people!

review_title: Extremely Toxic, Inhumane, Inflexible, Discriminatory, Micromanaging, Heavy-handed, Callous, Uncooperative Work Culture
pros:
1. Large size and global presence that create the false impression of broad career opportunities
2. Deceptively attractive benefits that trap especially mediocre employees into lifetime employment
cons:
I can never finish the list of cons. But here's a shortlist of most critical ones:
1. Extremely Toxic - Incessant mistrust and lack of cooperation among business units and coworkers even within the same dept.
2. Callous and Inhumane - Employees are virtually treated like dogs or slaves with a shocking disregard for human dignity, professional respect, and basic courtesy, let alone their occasional personal needs (health concerns or family obligations/emergencies).
3. Discriminatory - A senior executive in my functional area would drop F-bombs in conversations like handing out Halloween candy for Trick-or-Treat even in presence of female subordinates or peers... with total impunity! Lower level employees wouldn't even dare to engage in such behavior for the fear of legitimate legal action (including termination).
4. Stubbornly old-school - Lower level employees are required to show up at work everyday irrespective of their personal needs (health issues, child-care related emergencies, home/auto repairs, etc.) even when modern computing and internet technologies make it possible and easy to work remotely. Management simply doesn't trust people when they occasionally request permission to work remotely. It's ALWAYS my way or the highway.
5. Micromanaging - It's an understatement. Nano-managing would be more appropriate. Despite my two Masters degrees from two large, well-known U.S. state universities, I was not even allowed to directly engage with internal customers either over the phone, in person, or via email without my direct manager's knowledge and approval!
6. Callous and Inhumane - A hard-working coworker, an Abbvie lifer, was punished with no pay for taking longer time than initially expected for recovering from a surgery at a relatively old age.

I wouldn't recommend Abbvie as an employer to any talented, educated, ambitious and self-respecting person.
Advice to Management
The much publicized goal of creating a better work culture is just a joke. Leadership is shockingly clueless about 21-century employee-friendly practices at more desirable, progressive workplaces in the U.S and around the world. I would give them a negative million-star rating if such a rating was possible.
Helpful (11
advice_to_mgmt: The much publicized goal of creating a better work culture is just a joke. Leadership is shockingly clueless about 21-century employee-friendly practices at more desirable, progressive workplaces in the U.S and around the world. review_title: Dysfunctional Good Ole Boy/Girl Cliques Rule
pros: Easy for interns / fresh out of college and PhD individuals to score a managerial role without real word experience. Great boot camp -good place to get managerial experience right out of college and move on.
cons:
PhDs often find themselves in management roles without having to prove themselves with real world experiences, applying what they have learned. Also, people( soft) skills are not a requisite of managerial jobs.This only compounds the problems that are festering due to hiring interns and recent college grads in managerial roles.
Believe reviewers when they say that this is not a new company. The company is full of former Abbott employees in high rank positions. They all look and act the same- no diversity of thought/ no embracing of new was of doing things. The company is also a mix of Hospira and Baxter employees that had left Abbott and returned in higher ranking positions. The split from Abbott did not change ANYTHING; but, the name. Good ole boy/girl rules this company.
Processes and SOPs are often missing or have gaps that makes the environment chaotic.
Advice to Management
Management knows the problems and are very aware of the good ole boy/ girl clique. The company will implode due to the clique and from hiring the wrong person in the wrong positions (interns, PhDs, recent college grads in managerial roles; former Abbott /Hospira employees). 
Stop hiring interns,recent college grads and PhDs in roles that takes years to gain the maturity and experience needed to lead. Education in lieu of experience does not work. 
Stop the revolving door of former employees- Abbott, Hospira,Baxter - cultural change will NEVER happen with this same mix of employees
Infuse your organization( especially the middle management team) with others that did not work at Abbott, Hospira, Baxter
Quickly reorg the middle management team as they are stopping progress of the new company and culture. They are cliquish, territorial individuals that are holding on to old ways( Abbott ways) of doing things/ treating people and have the old culture embedded in Abbvie. They also refuse to accept others that do not possess their group think mentality. These things are all done as they await their move into senior leadership roles. Wake up senior management! Shake things up for the change you aspire / new company that is sold to potential employees.

pros: Commute is much easier than other Boston-area biotechs.
cons:
VICIOUS company politics, especially within engineering. Stale company culture, driven by long-service staff whose only qualification is starting with the old BASF back in the 90s. No leadership, management or people skills at all! Career opportunities are not merit-based but based solely on who you know and who your friends are. Ditto with merit raises - new focus on core behaviors being used by management as a tool to reward friends and punish perceive threats regardless of actual performance. All decisions based on company politics, nobody even pretends to look at facts. Actual high performers are either actively job hunting or already left. Pay is very poor compared to other companies. Even the cafeteria food is awful and overpriced. DON'T RISK IT - avoid this place!
Advice to Management
Quit. As soon as possible. Tell the new managers to pay attention to the culture survey results that you regularly ignore, and take REAL action to fix the problems. Eliminate the core behavior system or at least revamp it so that it's not completely subjective. Start holding middle management accountable for their actual performance, and start asking followup questions and demanding facts to cut throgh the sea of BS in the building.

review_title: The best job I've had up to now....
pros: Pay and benefits are quite good. My co-workers were great. The appear to be trying to improve the company culture based on feed-back from employees.
cons:
Very high stress place to work right now due to Humira coming off patent soon with the smell of desperation in the air. Huge discrepancies in pay and benefits from top to bottom.
Advice to Management
1 Don't lie to your employees and everyone else - we all knew the Shire deal was all about the tax shelter benefits - WHICH WAS LEAGLE, but you continued to deny after the rules changed and you dropped the deal.
2 Richard Gonzales lied on his resume about having a degree and there was no consequence. If any of us lied about qualifications, we would most likely be fired!
3 Your head of QA, being a former analyst, vastly favors the analytical group leaving your QA Micro badly under-supported. If they misidentify a contamination, multi-million dollar batches can be needlessly dumped. If they miss a contamination - it goes out. This puts an understaffed group under extreme pressure and is why no-one in the department want's Karen Wolf's old job - including people who could execute it better than she did.

review_title: Lots of potential, slow to change
pros: They are an exciting company and industry that is focused on 2 major things - Patients and Growth. They do truly care for the patient (as much as any pharma company can) and are willing to make tough decisions to grow the business.
cons:
They are a spin-off of Abbott Labs, a great company but also a very traditional, conservative one. AbbVie is in a fast-paced, progressive industry but as much as they say they are "new"...they aren't. The shadow of Abbott still looms large and it is a constant battle to get them to move quickly and change their ways. Especially upper management who say they want to empower teams but can't help but micromanage.
Advice to Management
Trust all these smart people you've hired in the past 3 years. Be willing to move quickly and trust that the work is being done. Trust doesn't mean blind ignorance...but you don't need to check the same slides 12 times.

review_title: Great company with tremendous potential but many kinks to still work through old-school culture
pros: Great pay and benefits. Very profitable, competitive and really trying to evolve into a more modern, bio-pharmaceutical company. There are new programs rolling out that are more health-focused, helping employees learning to cope with stress and encouraging more work-life balance. New drugs being offered are outstanding and show how great this company can be,
cons:
The culture needs a lot of work - there are many employees that migrated from Abbott and the hierarchical, political, old-school mindset needs a serious reboot. Pockets of the organization are still very silo'ed - like IT. There is no CIO / CTO and the organization suffers a great deal because IT is so disconnected from the business it supports and the Help Desk is not customer-service oriented. Older drugs like Synthroid either need to be reformulated or abandoned.
Advice to Management
IT customer service and true collaboration with the business needs to be addressed in order for the company to be agile. Dump legacy products or reboot them - they only bring down the great work being done in the new AbbVie regime. Really break down those old-school silos, dump the hierarchical stuff (like special parking for managers and higher) and promote a more agile workplace so work-life balance is truly attainable.
Helpful (3

Dump legacy products or reboot them - they only bring down the great work being done in the new AbbVie regime. review_title: Perhaps it depends on the department. Surprised.
pros:
Large-.
If this is your first professional job the place will be great as long as you have the ability to determine whether what you are learning is state of the art, or out of date. Many areas are understaffed, so there is lots of work. That is a pro and a con.
cons:
Work life balance bad.
Pay is low relative to the work life balance and competitors.
No merit bonus even for fairly high managers, just 5-7% profit sharing.
Dead wood: Either 20 year old Abbott management, or new management brought in from dying big pharma. 
Common statements: That is how we always have done it from middle management. I thought that last statement was something that nobody would ever say at any company. I almost fell over, the first time I heard it.
IT new and broken outsourced.
it is likely Abbvie will be bought out if it can't fill the Humara hole.
Very top management spins that the company is going to be a light nimble biotech, but the reality is very different in key areas.
401K middle of the road for Pharma.
No stock options for even middle management.
Current department has high turnover of new people joining jumping and being replaced by new people.
Advice to Management
Old management: Adapt, change, have a look, what your competitors have been doing for the last 20 years.or the department will be incorrectly outsourced, and you will have no job. There is a view that it is hard to recruit to Chicago. That is not the reason it is hard to recruit at Abbvie for certain departments.

review_title: To much emphasis based on Develop Program participants; not enough attention to development of finance employees
pros:
Dynamic environment often allows for great on-the-job learning opportunities.
Great people
Decent pay and benefits
cons:
Limited advancement - Like many companies advancement is based greatly on who you know. A major issue is management doesn't change much so the same people are promoted or given developmental opportunities. 
Not much diversity in leadership ranks
Still working out the kinks from the split from Abbott (systems, processes, etc.) which caused a lot of busy work and doesn't always allow time for analysis. I would recommend Abbvie to a friend but not in the Finance function.
Advice to Management
Focus more on development of employees and not processes (new PEx process, TMR)
More attention needed on the systems and IT (SAP, Help Desk, migrations)
Address changes that are not working (accounts payable issues etc.)
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt:
Focus more on development of employees and not processes (new PEx process, TMR)
More attention needed on the systems and IT (SAP, Help Desk, migrations)

pros: New and growing company. Offers great health benefit packages. Cafeterias in most buildings. Lots of selections for lunch. They are trying to improve culture by offering free food, entertainment at lunch hours & misc. .
cons:
Too many employees came over from Abbott and brought the bad culture with them. The management is very political. Upper management is seen as royalty and does not treat lower level employees well. People will undercut you for their personal gain. Company is so large you get lost in the shuffle. People were put into management positions that are not qualified.
Advice to Management
Be fair to your staff and don't fall to politics.
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: Be fair to your staff and don't fall to politics.

review_title: Love the highly collaborative culture and how the company is reinventing the large corporation
pros:
- Great onboarding experience, ensuring I had meetings and discussions with the key people and teams important to my role
- Outstanding career opportunities globally and a clear philosophy on talent management
- Highly competitive salary and benefits
- Strong patient focus throughout the business - I know my impact is much greater than impacting a company's bottom line, it is impacting people's health and wellness worldwide
- A unique "All for One" approach to decision making
- Outstanding product portfolio and innovation pipeline that will continue to keep the company in a leadership position in the industry
cons:
- A few too many meetings at times due to the scope of project teams and commitment to inclusiveness
- Lack of some key processes and workflows as a result of being a newer company that is redefining the way it works and operates
- Inconsistent workspace and environment - some workspace is very traditional while other is very modern and open (dependent on location)
Helpful (1

employee_status: Senior Manager in North Chicago, IL
pros: Evolving culture, great people, dedication to work in healthcare, expansive career growth, globally minded. Since transitioning from Abbott the shift towards a more nimble biotech is evident in the work that is done. The focus on a successful future is talked about on day to day basis. The vision of being a patient centric company is coming to life. Benefits are strong; onsite day care (like).
cons:
Campus is spread out and requires day to day planning to get to meetings, etc. Having most or all employees at the same location would be beneficial for cross collaboration. Some employees are on the train of change and others are still at the station, challenging to get new ideas through.

review_title: Senior leadership understands the value of a strong corporate culture!
pros: Many opportunities to take on new, challenging assignments, but you can't wait for someone to offer. You need to step up and ask. Solid benefits program, including diverse 401K and Pension.
cons:
Legacy Abbott culture at middle-management level needs to be addressed. Senior leadership has made an impact here, but more opportunities exist. Medical benefits could be better for a health care company; the programs change significantly in cost/coverage on a year to year basis.
Advice to Management
Keep up what you're doing and don't significant change course until you see the progress you started.

review_title: Politics, Fragmented and Limited Opportunities for Growth
pros: Great products to work on and some very passionate marketing staff. Over the years, patient focus has increased significantly which really helps drive and motivate across the organization.
cons:
Organization is fragmented and often not aligned to the same goals. There is high amount of individuals that are willing to lie, talk behind backs to create divisions. It can often be a very hostile environment despite all working towards the same goal and for the same company? After working for two other Fortune 500s, this is my first experience of this level of hostility and division between departments. The new behaviors seem to outline the right direction, but there's lack of accountability around these measures.
Advice to Management
Finding ways to make everyone more accountable for teamwork, even if it includes balancing power could lead to great traction with the behaviors and a better culture. Very negative ratings on the culture survey in years past were met with ambivalence by past senior management. Senior Management vision, often not shared by others within the organization.

pros: Work-life balance is great. Direct leadership is also good, not perfect but good enough. Compensation and salary are good but that is a continuation of Abbott salary. All the good things are carryover from Abbott. Abbott was not perfect but AbbVie could be so much better.
cons:
Upper management hired after the separation from Abbott demonstrate lack of effective leadership. When no one from the original organization is promoted to positions they clearly qualify for then something is not right. Newly hired DVPs are completely disconnected from the reality of a very fluid industry.
Advice to Management
Listen to the people who work there about how the industry operates . However not liking the reality on the ground and what you are hearing and then hiring a consultant group to tell you what you want to hear is pretty foolish and a waste of talent and money. Changes being made in isolation from the greater AbbVie community will likely have negative consequences on overall company performance.
